Message from the Superintendent
MAKE SURE YOU ARE CHECKING INSTUDENTS: Are you checking in with your teachers?
Be sure to check your emails for important communications. You can find links to your teacher's web page and email by going to your school's website.
DISTANCE LEARNINGDistance learning is in full swing at AUSD, here a Carrisa Plains Polecat watching Doug from Mystery ScienAce LIVE! He had the kids use aluminum foil to make 3D visualization! How fun!!
To visit Mystery Doug Live visit https://mysteryscience.com/live
Monterey Road 4th graders from Mrs. Laurie's class had a virtual field trip to La Purisima Mission on Thursday.
http://www.lapurisimamission.org
BATTLE OF THE BOOKSOur District Librarian, Kris Bell, has put together a list of places you can find Battle Books. A lot of them can be found in ebook or audiobook format. Click on the link below to find out where you can get access.
Battle of the Books
OPERA SLO's "CHIME IN" SERIESOperaSLO has created a Chime-In" series, and a program that presents educational music videos on the two TV stations operated by our County Office of Education. Visit the links below to see what these talented artists have put together for our community while we are sheltering at home.
Opera SLO Youtube
SLOCOE TV
Food Service Letter to Parents
Versión en Español
A MESSAGE FROM SUPERINTENDENT BUTLER
CHROMEBOOK DISTRIBUTION Many schools handed out Chromebooks this week, giving students the ability to engage in home based learning and also getting a chance to see some of their principals, teachers and other amazing staff members. Monterey Road greeted their students and parents with lots of fun noise makers and enthusiasm while Creston had their mascot waving to everyone that came through, all while keeping a safe 6 foot distance. A big THANK YOU to all of AUSD's staff as they keep things moving for our students!
Carrisa Plains Polecats
Creston Cougars
Monterey Road Mustangs
Click here for a video from Monterey Road Elementary
FIRST WEEK OF ﻿HOME BASED LEARNINGHope everybody's first week of home based learning went somewhat smoothly, if you have any questions please direct them to your student's teacher or principal.
Here is the academic plan for Home Based Learning that began this week (4/1/2020). Please see the attached document for more detailed information of the academic plan. Additionally, we have created a schedule for the distribution of Chromebooks for students in grades 1-6. School principals have sent out each school's schedule.
We look forward to embarking on this new endeavour together with you. Click on the flyer below to read more.
CIF SCHOLAR ATHLETE CAEL COOPEREight time Varsity Letterman, Cael Cooper, was awarded the CIF's Scholar Athlete award for this year.
“It was honestly a little surprising to me because I was just not expecting it,” Cooper said. “With everything that has been going on with the school shutting down and everything I kind of figured, I would never hear about it again, but it was actually a good surprise when our athletic director Facetimed me and told me the news.”
Read the full article in the Atascadero News, linked below.
CONGRATULATIONS CAEL!
Atascadero News

STEAM MINECRAFTER CAMP STEAM Minecrafter camp is coming back to Atascadero for its 3rd summer! We hope you'll join us once again, as we are planning new worlds and new engaging STEAM activities.
This year's camp is June 8-12, from 9-3 pm. Click on this link below for more details.
Minecrafter Camp

h4.span: CRAZY DAYS AT CRESTON ELEMENTARY SCHOOL!

div.div: ﻿Creston's Cougars had a blast participating in event days, such as CRAZY HAT DAY and did so much reading while celebrating Dr. Seuss Week!

img.alt: Crazy Hat day at Creston Elementary

div.div: Isabella Otter won the National Championship in Indoor Archery, read all about her past and present wins in the Atascadero News.
READ ACROSS AMERICABoard member Mrs. Kuhnle visited Carrisa Plains to read aloud to the students during Read Across America week.

REGIONAL SCIENCE BOWL COMPETITIONAtascadero Middle School Science Team had so much fun competing in this year's Regional Science Bowl, they worked hard to overcome some nerves and were VERY impressive in their performance! We are so proud of how the team competed! They worked very hard throughout the school year during the Science Bowl Saint's Block and studied countless hours on their own time. We had 3 tutors from Cal Poly helping them to prepare during Saint's Block.
16 teams across Southern/Central California competed in the Regional Science Bowl at Cal Poly. Only 3 teams in SLO county participated: Atascadero, Templeton and SLO Classical Academy.
﻿AMS had the only all-female team in the competition! This was their 2nd year competing.
Atascadero News

AHS GREYBOTSThe AHS Greybots took 1st place at Mamba Stadium in Thousand Oaks.
Ranked 1st in the qualifications matches out of 41 robots, they also won the Autonomous Award by Ford lead by Oliver and 6 of the 12 Greybot programmers this year.
THINKING MAPS NIGHT AT SAN GABRIEL ELEMENTARY SCHOOLSan Gabriel held a Thinking Maps parent night. Students got to help their parents learn the 8 different maps.

img.alt: Thinking Maps parents night at San Gabriel Elementary

div.div: Trustee Donn Clickard and Mrs. Leoni read Dr. Seuss books to the class and Superintendent Butler in celebration of Dr. Seuss' birthday on Monday, March 2!

img.alt: Trustee Donn Clickard and Mrs. Leoni read Dr. Seuss books to the class and Superintendent Butler in celebration of Dr. Seuss' birthday on Monday, March 2!

h4.span: Core Value of Excellence - Deri Kaye Ripel

div.div: Assistant Superintendent Curt Eichperger congratulates Deri Kaye Ripel on her recognition from the Board of Trustees for the AUSD Core Value of Excellence. Deri Kay recently received the Champions Program Award for California, Nevada and Arizona, being the only recipient for all three states. She will be invited back to Kentucky to compete against other regional recipients later in the year. The Board of Trustees and Deri Kaye's family were happy to congratulate her on this awesome achievement and thanked her for the wonderful care of the students before and after school. Way to go Deri Kaye!!

img.alt: Assistant Superintendent Curt Eichperger congratulates Deri Kaye Ripel

div.div: Creston Elementary School Principal Sarah Betz was happy to have her picture taken with Reagan, Jaxon, and Levi who gave the Trustees a hand delivered invitation to Creston's Open House and Ribbon Cutting Ceremony scheduled for March 31st. The three young men also lead the pledge of allegiance to open the evening's Board of Trustees Meeting. Keep up the good work boys!

Archer National ChampionSchool Board Student Representative and Atascadero High School junior Bella Otter was congratulated by the Board of Trustees for receiving National Championship at a recent archery competition. Bella scored 1163 pts. out of 1200 pts. to win the Compound Cadet Women division. Way to go Bella!!

img.alt: School Board Student Representative and Atascadero High School junior Bella Otter was congratulated by the Board of Trustees

div.div:
PCHS Volunteers Recognized for AUSD's Core Value of Teamwork
Paloma Creek High School and ACE Academy Principal Chris Balogh recognized two of his school's community volunteers for the AUSD Core Value of Teamwork. Linda Campeggi, retired Morro Bay High School teacher, has been volunteering since 2015 and is an indispensable help at the site with her organizational skills and her expertise as a proofreader. Rich Johnson shares his interest with career exploration and has helped organize the annual career days as well as created 'Mobile Career Days' where he takes the students out to various businesses and shares viable alternatives for their career paths. Principal Balogh thanked both for their diligence and generosity towards the students and staff. Thank you Linda and Rich!

img.alt: Chris Balogh recognized two of his school's community volunteers for the AUSD Core Value of Teamwork.

tr.td:
Our Mission, Vision, Core Values, Graduate Profile and District Goals
Welcome to the Atascadero Unified School District, where we are dedicated to students and committed to excellence. One of the unique strengths of AUSD is the talent and teamwork that is exemplified by our students and staff. Through this talent and teamwork we aim to produce the top students in the nation who are college, career, and citizenship ready. In addition to our world class graduate profile, we also set high expectations for our students, staff, and parents through our core values of respect, integrity, teamwork, and excellence.
Thomas Butler, Superintendent

Graduate Profile
Preparing the Top Students in the Nation
Critical Thinker Our graduates are original thinkers. They observe, they wonder, they create, and they have the ability to solve real world problems.
Effective Communicator Our graduates convey their thoughts and responses clearly and comprehensively. They have highly refined reading, writing, speaking, and listening skills.
Teammate Our graduates are skilled collaborators and understand the value of achieving common goals through teamwork.
Self-Directed Individual Our graduates accept responsibility for their learning. They recognize their strengths and work to their full potential. They value learning as a life long skill.
College and Career Ready Scholar Our graduates navigate the pathways that connect education and employment to a productive, rewarding and secure life. Responsible and Contributing Citizen Our graduates display integrity and civic responsibility. They aim to make a positive contribution to their communities.

br.br:
The Board of Trustees is committed to providing equal opportunity for all individuals in education. District programs, activities, and practices shall be free from discrimination based on gender, race, color, actual or perceived ancestry, national origin, ethnic group identification, age, religion, marital or parental status, physical or mental disability, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, or genetic information, the perception of one or more of such characteristics, or association with a person or group with one or more of these actual or perceived characteristics. Atascadero Unified School District is an Equal Opportunity Employer.
Atascadero Unified School District complies with the requirements of the U.S. Office of Civil Rights laws, such as the Fair Employment Practices Act, Title IX Regulations, Section 504, Title II and ADA requirements in employment and education programs and activities.
Title IX Officer: Assist. Supt. Human Resources, 5601 West Mall Atascadero, CA (805) 462-4200
504 Coordinator: Dir. Student Intervention Services, 4507 Del Rio Road, Atascadero, CA (805) 462-4230
